title.narrative: Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) and Natural Gas Infrastructure Reverse Trade Mission (RTM), through Global Marketing & Communications, Inc.

description.narrative: This USTDA-funded reverse trade mission (RTM) supports U.S. private sector participation in the implementation of gas infrastructure in Pakistan. The RTM supports USTDA's goal of developing gas infrastructure in emerging markets and the Government of Pakistan's intent to expand LNG imports and infrastructure. The RTM will share best practices for value-based natural gas infrastructure planning and technical capacity building and support opportunities for U.S. exports to Pakistan.

title.narrative: Definitional Mission - Biogas-Based Power Generation, through Innovation Network LLC

description.narrative: This definitional mission (DM) to Pakistan is conducting a market assessment as well as identifying and evaluating opportunities related to biogas-based power generation in the country's agribusiness sector for USTDA funding consideration.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Landhi Cattle Colony Biomethane Project, through Seaspire Advisors, LLC

description.narrative: This grant funds a feasibility study (FS) for Times Group (Private) Limited, an engineering and construction company in Pakistan, to deploy anaerobic digester units to process cattle waste into biomethane and fertilizer. This feasibility study will help the Times Group evaluate the economic feasibility of the waste to biomethane project; develop technical specifications, designs, and plans; review and identify necessary permits; and analyze potential environmental and social impacts. The feasibility study will be conducted on a sole-source basis by Seaspire Advisors, Limited Liability Corporation (LLC).

description.narrative: This $1,026,000 grant supports a feasibility study (FS) to evaluate the technical, economic, and financial viability of a 400-435 megawatt gas turbine combined cycle plant (Project) in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Province of Pakistan. KP Province has significant gas reserves yet suffers from chronic power shortages. The grantee is the Pakhtunkhwa Energy Development Organization, the entity of the provincial government that has responsibility for energy project development.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Back-Up Power Conversion to Methanol Fuel Cells, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: This $462,520 grant supported a feasibility study and pilot project for Warid Telecom to determine the economic and operational feasibility of introducing methanol-based fuel cells and sodium-metal halide batteries to reduce the energy consumption and improve the reliability of a major mobile telephony network in Pakistan. Warid Telecom has more than 18 million subscribers and more than 4,700 base transceiver stations (BTS). At least 90 percent of the 50,000 BTS sites in Pakistan serving the countrys 118 million mobile phone users have permanent diesel generators providing backup power many hours each day, year round. Methanol-based fuel cells combined with sodium batteries would be a replacement for the diesel generator sets and subsequently those of other carriers.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Banking Information Technology Modernization, through Business Council for International Understanding

description.narrative: This reverse trade mission (RTM) familiarized Pakistan public and private sector banks with U.S. technologies and solutions for the banking sector, particularly relating to mobile and internet banking, anti-money laundering solutions, fraud analytics, and customer relationship management solutions. The RTM assisted Pakistan's efforts to modernize its banking sector and broaden Pakistanis' access to financial services.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Biomass Power Plant and Waste Heat Recovery for Cement Producer, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: This $769,000 grant supported a feasibility study for PLC Limited (PLC), a publicly traded Pakistani cement and concrete producer, to establish the technical and economic viability of incorporating a 35-50 megawatt biomass-fired power plant, a waste heat recovery system, and energy efficiency upgrades to mitigate or reduce dependency on grid power at a major cement plant.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Cold Storage Infrastructure Network, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: This $329,328 grant partially funded a feasibility study to support the establishment of twelve cold storage facilities at strategic locations within five geographical areas throughout Pakistan. In Pakistan, 20 to 40 percent of perishable products are lost to spoilage before they can be consumed because of inadequate post-harvest handling and lack of refrigeration. The project will improve the cold chain and the post-harvest system through commercial development of cold storage facilities, while ultimately further strengthening U.S.-Pakistan economic cooperation goals.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - POWER SECTOR, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: This $263,000 technical assistance grant to Pakistan's National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) assists in reviewing NEPRA's tariff determination practices for various technologies/fuels, especially as they relate to renewables, and proposes suitable modifications/changes in the determination process. This assistance seeks to enhance renewable energy sector strategies, industry standards, and legal and regulatory regimes, which in turn will help create a favorable business and trade environment for renewable energy development in Pakistan.

title.narrative: Orientation Visit - INTERMODAL FREIGHT TRANSPORTATION, through The Cornell Group, Inc.

description.narrative: This orientation visit (OV) introduced Pakistani public and private sector delegates to U.S. technologies and products currently employed for efficiently improving and managing intermodal containerized freight transportation. The OV included delegates who met with U.S. private and public sector entities active in this arena and attended the Intermodal Expo and TransComp Exhibition in November 2009.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - COLD STORAGE INFRASTRUCTURE NETWORK, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: This $329,328 grant partially funds a feasibility study to support establishing twelve cold storage facilities at strategic locations within five geographical areas throughout Pakistan. In Pakistan, 20 to 40 percent of perishable products are lost to spoilage before they can be consumed because of inadequate post-harvest handling and lack of refrigeration. The project will improve the cold chain and the post-harvest system through commercial development of cold storage facilities, while ultimately further strengthening U.S.-Pakistan economic cooperation goals.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - BEACONHOUSE SCHOOLS SOLAR PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER SYSTEMS, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: USTDA support of $299,896 funds a feasibility study to determine the technical, economic, and financial feasibility of installing solar photovoltaic (PV) power systems at hundreds of private schools in Pakistan that are part of the Beaconhouse school system. Educational Services (private) Limited ("ESL"), the owner of the Beaconhouse schools brand and the largest private educational services company in Pakistan, is the Grantee. The Study seeks to establish the viability of installing solar PV panels at educational institutions as a capital investment, as a hedge against foreseeable fuel and energy price increases, as a back-up power supply to continue educational activities in the events of power outages and damaging brownouts, and as an asset to the educational process. Solar power has the potential to provide uninterrupted power to schools at a time of frequent load shedding, to lower the overall cost of power, and to demonstrate science and technology at work to pupils. This project could serve as an example for rollout horizontally to other school systems, and vertically to the residential, commercial, and small industrial sectors.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - KARACHI INTEGRATED SMART GRID SYSTEM, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: USTDA support of $510,475 funds a feasibility study to determine the viability of an integrated Smart Grid system in greater Karachi for substantially reducing electricity losses and improving the efficiency of utility operations. An objective of the feasibility study is to define the scope for a major capital investment in a large Smart Grid pilot project. Karachi Electric Supply Company Limited (KESC), the only private distribution utility in Pakistan, is the Grantee. KESC's distribution system has very high losses: as much as 40 percent or roughly 1,000 MW is lost through technical line losses and administrative losses. This USTDA-funded Study has the potential to have a significant developmental impact in Pakistan through much needed energy infrastructure improvements that currently constrain economic performance, the technology transfer associated with Smart Grid technology, and supporting market-oriented reforms to relieve the problem of "free riders".

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

sector.narrative: Electric power transmission and distribution (centralised grids)

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - BIOMASS COGENERATION AT BULLEH SHAH PAPER MILL, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: This $289,125 grant funds a feasibility study for Packages Limited ("Packages"), a publicly traded Pakistani packaging company, to determine the best option to utilize various paper and agricultural wastes from a recently built paper mill, to develop biomass cogeneration at Packages' Bulleh Shah paper mill in Kasur, Punjub province, Pakistan. The Study assesses and recommends one of two options to utilize the waste from the paper mill and potentially local biomass resources: (a) installing a new 50-ton per hour biomass boiler that would generate 10 MW of electrical power in the existing system; or (b) a significantly larger biomass project of up to 60 MW based on the available fuel supply, interconnection, site and financing constraints.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - TRADE INFORMATION GATEWAY REAL-TIME EXCHANGE (TIGRE) PROJECT, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: This $933,273 grant partially funds a feasibility study and pilot project to assess the viability and application of a Trade Information Gateway Real-Time Exchange (TIGRE) software solution for cargo movement operations in and around the main ports of Karachi, Pakistan. Megatransport Private Limited has identified NTELX Inc. as the sole-source contractor. The TIGRE system will help support Megatransport's efforts to promote efficient and secure trade by allowing cargo and transportation logistical movements to be tracked via a web-based platform.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - PAKISTAN: FEASIBILITY STUDY: EXPANDED MAINTENANCE, REPAIR, AND OVERHAUL FACILITY FOR PAKISTAN INTERNATIONAL AIRLINES, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: USTDA support of $864,002 funds a feasibility study for an expanded Maintenance, Repair, and Overhaul (MRO) Facility for Pakistan International Airlines (PIA). The Study develops a market assessment and business plan for PIA's expanded MRO facility, as well as the necessary technical requirement and cost estimates. The comprehensive facility will be able to service engines, landing gears, airframes, and aircraft components. Developing this updated MRO facility through USTDA funds will help to further strengthen the U.S. commercial aviation presence in Pakistan that should lead to significant U.S. exports in equipment and services. This USTDA-funded Study also has the potential to have a significant developmental impact in Pakistan through crucial infrastructure improvements, human capacity building through the Study's training/capacity-building component, and technology transfer from exposure to advanced aviation safety and testing technologies.

description.narrative: This $170,000 definitional mission identifies and evaluates opportunities in Pakistan's information communication and technology (ICT) sector for USTDA funding consideration. In an effort to encourage U.S. company participation in ICT projects in Pakistan, USTDA will consider funding support for activities including, but not limited to, e-governance, broadband access and disaster/emergency preparedness.

title.narrative: Definitional Mission - ENERGY SECTOR PROJECTS, through Energy Markets Group

description.narrative: This $175,000 Definitional Mission identifies and evaluates opportunities in the energy sector in Pakistan for USTDA funding consideration. The Pakistani economy is constrained as a result of severe and unscheduled power outages of four to fifteen hours a day. This energy sector DM builds off the success of the previous energy sector DM in Pakistan that has already resulted in close to $1.7 million in USTDA funding.

title.narrative: Definitional Mission - TRANSPORTATION SECTOR PROJECTS, through Interdisciplinary Research Consultants

description.narrative: This $185,000 definitional mission identifies and evaluates opportunities in the transportation sector in Pakistan for USTDA funding consideration. Pakistan currently does not have the supportive transportation infrastructure necessary for achieving the trade and transport logistics effeciencies critical for economic stabilization, sustained growth and international competitiveness. U.S. companies play an important role in the development of the transport sector, and USTDA support would further strengthen U.S. engagement while lending support to Pakistan's program for Removing Infrastructure Bottlenecks through Public-Private Partnership, one of the nine pillars of the GOP's poverty reduction strategy.

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Grid Modernization Pilot Project, through Government Of Pakistan

description.narrative: This $924,290 technical assistance (TA) funds a grid modernization assessment for a pilot project in greater Islamabad to serve as the basis for the deployment of Smart Grid technologies. The TA focuses on evaluating and analyzing a pilot area of the Islamabad Electric Supply Companys (IESCOs) distribution system, conducting a high-level gap analysis of the present system infrastructure versus a suite of potential Smart Grid investments, and then identifying the appropriate combination of technologies that will most effectively upgrade the capabilities of IESCOs distribution system. Project implementation would improve the ability of IESCO to operate and maintain its systems efficiency, form the basis for planning capital investments, improve service to customers, and establish a framework for future Smart Grid deployment.
